title: EU Brexit negotiator: UK demands on single market are impossible - as it happened | Politics | The Guardian
summary: greeks deny planning to use brexit talks to try to recover elgin marbles .
tory party has 'firm , fixed view ' that may should stay as leader , says 1922 committee chair .
osborne 's evening standard compares may to 'living dead in second-rate horror film '
davis says uk will take into account its moral obligations as well as its legal obligations in its brexit offer to eu .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: michel barnier , the eu 's chief brexit negotiator , has said there has been no decisive progress '' on key issues in talks with the uk , as the two sides hit deadlock over the divorce bill .

theresa may has secured a much hoped-for formal commitment from japan that both countries will seek to instantly replace an eu-japan trade deal with a facsimile equivalent for the uk when brexit happens .
may has reiterated her call for china to put more pressure on north koreato limit its missile programmes as the uk tries to get beijing to participate in imposing tougher sanctions on pyongyang .
graham brady , chair of the conservative backbench 1992 committee , has said that his party has a 'firm , fixed view ' that may should stay on as leader .
( see 5.35pm . )
he spoke after other senior party figures cast doubt on her insistence that she could lead the party into the next election .
the uk government is failing to uphold disabled people 's rights across a range of areas from education , work and housing to health , transport and social security , a un inquiry has found .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: tory party has 'firm , fixed view ' that may should stay as leader , says 1922 committee chair
text: turning back to the conservative party leadership , theresa may has just received a significant endorsement ; in fact , about the most important endorsement a conservative prime minister can receive .

graham brady , who as chairman of the 1922 committee is the shop steward for tory mps , has told bbc news that it is the firm , fixed view '' of his colleagues that she should stay - at least for the time being .
he told the programme : the conservative party has a firm , fixed view .
we really do n't want to have a leadership election , or a change of leader .
we recognise , as theresa may was saying [ at her press conference this morning - see 11.24am ] that there are big , important and complex tasks that need to be done .
we as the party in government have the obligation to do those .
we are here to serve the nation interest .

and that is served by the kind of successful diplomacy that we have seen from theresa may in japan i think the comment that theresa made [ about wanting to fight the next election as leader ] was far more a rebuttal of an unfounded story that was put about in some of the tabloids last week which suggested she had fixed the date in 2019 to resign as prime minister , which had no foundation whatsoever but kept much of the british media chattering away for several days .
brady was referring to a sunday mirror story at the weekend saying may had set friday 30 august 2019 as her departure date .
however , brady was rather more opaque when asked if personally wanted may to lead the party into the next election .
he replied : i want theresa may to carry on leading the conservative party .
i have no plans to change that position .
i think she has a big and important job to do .
she is doing it well , and she deserves our support .
anyone at all familiar with the way politicians speak will know that , when you hear the words no plans '' , someone is being shifty and that , metaphorically , it 's time to count the spoons .
the presenter then asked brady if his answer meant may leading the party into the next election .
brady replied : one would assume so .
it was a rather odd reply .
one '' might assume that that is what brady meant .
but the presenter was trying to find out what brady himself thought he meant , and he did not get a very clear reply .
graham brady .
this is from stefan leifert , a correspondent for the german broadcaster zdf .
i do n't speak german , but it is not hard to work out what paralleluniversum '' means .
stefan leifert ( @ stefanleifert ) kein fortschritt , nirgends .
von brexit-verhandlungen in paralleluniversen : here is an extract from the article .
auch die wahrnehmungen über das bisher erreichte gehen weit auseinander .

eu-chefunterhändler michel barnier bekundet , weit von echtem fortschritt entfernt '' zu sein , während sein britischer counterpart , brexit-minister david davis , von sehr produktiven verhandlungstagen '' spricht .
willkommen im paralleluniversum .
and here is how it reads after being wrung through google translate , with a bit of tidying up from me .
perceptions about the achievements so far are also far apart .
eu chief negotiator michel barnier says they are far from real progress '' , while his british counterpart , brexit minister david davis , speaks of very productive negotiating days '' .
welcome to the parallel universe .

the economist 's tom nuttall says eurocrats are saying that if theresa may repeats her no deal is better than a bad deal '' argument in the big brexit speech she is expected to give in september , she will set back the brexit negotiations by half a year .
here is an extract from the article he has tweeted .
the eu blames domestic politics for stopping the british from being clearer about what they want .
and negotiators were dismayed to see theresa may , the prime minister , return this week to her mantra that no deal is better than a bad deal '' .
next month she is to deliver a speech on brexit .
if she says the same thing , says one eurocrat , the talks will be set back by six months .
tom nuttall ( @ tom nuttall ) plus our latest on brexit .
if may repeats `` no deal '' mantra in sept , talks will be set back 6 months , warn eurocrats .

documents.title: greeks deny planning to use brexit talks to try to recover elgin marbles
text: despite the dramatic tone of brexit negotiations ( so far ) the greek government has dispelled speculation that it could exploit the issue to raise the ever-thorny question of returning the elgin , or parthenon , marbles to greece .
the rumour mill has been rife in recent days that athens will use what activists are calling the best opportunity yet to get london to give up elgin 's loot .
any deal would have to be ratified by all 27 eu states - raising the prospect that greece could force britain 's hand in the row .
but the leftist-led government is categorically denying any such scenario .
speaking to the guardian , officials described the move as extravagant and silly .
it is out of the question , '' said costas douzinas , who heads the greek parliament 's foreign relation 's committee .

there is a very good argument , however , that in 2021 when the country marks the bicentenary of the revolution [ greece 's war of independence from the ottoman empire ] the british museum loans us a few good pieces for the period of the celebrations .

like most politicians in athens , douzinas , who happens to be a well-respected academic at london university in addition to being a mp in the governing syriza party , believes a deal will eventually be struck .
but he worries about britain 's declining influence before an accord with europe is eventually reached .
there is a sense that the mood is changing , that as britain turns away from europe anglophilia is also beginning to go , '' he lamented .
i know of people who are now looking at other places to study and i fear that greek shipping and business interests will do the same . ''

a frieze which forms part of the elgin marbles '' , taken from the parthenon in athens , greece almost two hundred years ago by the british aristocrat , the earl of elgin , at the british museum in london .
barclay/getty images

the department for exiting the european union ( dexeu ) has published an updated chart showing where the uk and the eu agree on the issue of citizens ' rights , where they disagree , and where further work is needed .
the july version of the document ( pdf ) identified 22 areas of agreement ( 50 % of the total ) , 14 areas of disagreement ( 32 % ) and eight areas where further work was needed ( 18 % ) .
there has been some progress .
today 's version ( pdf ) identifies 37 areas of agreement ( 56 % ) , 21 areas of disagreement ( 32 % ) and eight areas where further work is needed ( 12 % ) .
in his speech at the press conference , david davis , the brexit secretary , listed some of the new areas where agreement has been reached .

documents.title: osborne 's evening standard compares may to 'living dead in second-rate horror film '
text: evening standard editorials are almost always worth reading now that george osborne is editor .
in today 's , the standard compares theresa may to the living dead in a second-rate horror film '' .
george osborne ( @ george osborne ) and here 's our editorial @ twitterid on mrs may 's bid to stay here is how it starts .
like the living dead in a second-rate horror film , the premiership of theresa may staggers on oblivious .
this was not supposed to be in the script .
it was universally acknowledged by tory mps after her disastrous , wooden performance in the election campaign that she could never lead them in to an election again .
to stave off an immediate execution in june , she adopted two tactics .
first , like king charles i before her , she offered up the heads of her deeply unpopular advisers instead .
it was n't my fault that i 've alienated my entire cabinet and produced a vote-destroying manifesto , it was theirs , '' she pleaded .
second , she told tory mps : you do n't have to go to the trouble of getting rid of me , i 'll jump before i 'm pushed . ''
or at least that 's what the tory parliamentary party thought they heard when she said to them on the monday after the election : i will serve as long as you want me . ''

the settled assumption until this week was that mrs may would soak up all the damage to the party 's reputation coming in the brexit negotiations and then hand the premiership over in the summer of 2019 to an unsullied successor .

this morning , those mps have woken up to discover that mrs may wants to go on and on after the general election osborne , who was sacked as chancellor by may last year , described her as a dead woman walking '' .
the writer of today 's leader seems to have taken than metaphor as his or her inspiration .
guy verhofstadt , the european parliament 's chief brexit negotiator , has told cnbc that he fears that some british brexiteers do n't even want a deal with the eu .
( he does not say - in this clip , at least - to whom he is referring . )
guy verhofstadt ( @ guyverhofstadt ) i fear that some of the # brexit hardliners do n't want to negotiate .
watch more here :

the irish foreign minister simon coveney says there is a lot of work '' to do before the brexit talks can move on to phase two , where the eu and the uk will discuss a future trade deal , my colleague patrick wintour reports .
patrick wintour ( @ patrickwintour ) simon coveney irish fm today 1 ) `` lot of work '' to do before move to future relations issues 2 ) uk in sm & cu best way to stop hard border .
here is the press association photographer stefan rousseau 's photo du jour '' from theresa may 's japan trip .
stefan rousseau ( @ stefanrousseau ) photo du jour : theresa may arrives at pm office in tokyo for meeting with japan 's national security council by stefan rousseau/pa
here is the express 's nick gutteridge on the significance of what michel barnier was saying about the importance of the european parliament .
( see 2.31pm . )
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 1 ) small takeout from barnier-davis ding-dong .
notable that barnier deliberately bigged up ( over-egged frankly ) influence of eu parliament .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 2 ) during speech he said : 'the ep very early took a very strong stand with its resolution .
please do n't underestimate the role of the ep . '
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 3 ) now , ep has no formal role .
it has a brexit rapporteur , the famous guy verhofstadt , who liaises with commission/council & reports back .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 4 ) technically , its only role in the whole process is to either vote through or veto any deal the commission & council agree with the uk .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 5 ) however , the ep is the most hardline of all the institutions and barnier was clearly trying to give impression his hands are tied by it .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 6 ) in reality , they 're really not .
most observers believe the ep will basically do what it 's told by the commission when the time comes .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) 7 ) so is this excuse preparation by barnier ?
if the uk walks out will he point to verhofstadt & co to deflect blame from himself/eu council ?
for more detail on how the european parliament is adopting a more hardline approach to brexit than the european council ( ie , more hostile to britain ) , see this post from my blog in april .
the snp says today 's press conference shows that the government 's approach to the brexit talks is failing .
this is from peter grant mp , its europe spokesman at westminster .
the tory government 's approach to the brexit negotiations from day one has been one of desperate disarray , rather than constructive engagement .

we 're into the third round of talks and the contradictions from the press conference today shows that the uk government does n't appear even to be in the same room , never mind the same page , on setting out its key positions and finding common ground in these negotiations .

the current strategy of bulldozing our eu partners into a deal , and excluding the devolved administrations from having so much as a say will inevitably lead to the uk failing to make any positive progress on the key issues of the border with ireland , the divorce bill and the rights of eu nationals .
the tories ' top priority is keeping their party together and the hard-liners on board no matter the cost to scottish jobs and living standards .

we 're at a critical junction in these negotiations and it 's time for the tory government to accept the overwhelming case for staying in the single market for the sake of the economy , business and jobs .

documents.title: davis/barnier press conference - full summary
text: here is a full summary of the davis/barnier press conference , with all the key quotes .
michel barnier , the eu 's chief brexit negotiator , claimed that britain was making demands relating to single market access that were simply impossible '' .
in his opening remarks he said : the uk decided to leave the european union .
the uk government decided to leave the single market and the customs union .
we respect this sovereign decision .
but one thing is clear : the single market , the eu capacity to regulate , to supervise , to enforce our laws , must not and will not be undermined by brexit .
the uk strongly contributed to the development of our single market which is the foundation of the eu .
it understands well , very well , how it works .
the european council guidelines state that the union will preserve its autonomy of decision-making .
the uk wants to take back control , it wants to adopt its own standards and regulations .
but it also wants to have these standards recognised automatically in the eu .
that is what uk papers ask for .
this is simply impossible .
you can not be outside the single market and shape its legal order .
he repeated the point during the q & a , accusing the british government of nostalgia '' .

he said : when i read some of the papers that david has sent me on behalf of the british government , in some proposals i see a sort of nostalgia in the form of specific requests which would amount to continuing to enjoy the benefits of the single market and eu membership without actually being part of it .
maybe i 've got the wrong end of the stick .
maybe there is no nostaglia .
but , as i said earlier , brexit means brexit .
leaving the single market means leaving the single market .
if that is what has been decided , there will be consequences .
david davis , the brexit secretary , responded to this point by saying it was wrong to mistake belief in the free market for nostalgia .
barnier said there was no decisive progress '' on the key issue in this week 's talks .
we did not get any decisive progress on any of the principal subjects .
barnier strongly hinted that , given the current rate of progress , he would not be advising eu leaders to let the talks move on to phase two in october .
currently the talks focus on withdrawal issues , but the uk wants the talks to move to phase two , covering the future trade relationship , as soon as possible .

the eu says it will agree this when sufficient progress has been made on withdrawal issues ( citizens ' rights , ireland and the brexit bill '' ) and it had been hoped that this would happen in october .

barnier said : at the current state of progress we are quite far from being able to say that sufficient progress has taken place , sufficient for me to be able to recommend to the european council that it engage in discussions on the future relationship between the uk and eu at the same time as we would , during the course of 2018 , go on working on finalising the exit and withdrawal agreement .
barnier claimed that this week 's talks showed that the uk did not feel legally obliged to honour its legal finacial obligations after brexit .
in his opening remarks he said : eu taxpayers should not pay at 27 for the obligations undertaken at 28 .
this would not be fair .
in july , the uk recognised that it has obligations beyond the brexit date .
but this week the uk explained that these obligations will be limited to their last payment to the eu budget before departure .
yet we have joint obligations towards third countries .
for example : we have guaranteed long-term loans to ukraine , together .
we jointly support development in africa , the caribbean and pacific countries through the european development fund .
after this week , it is clear that the uk does not feel legally obliged to honour these obligations after departure .
we have also jointly committed to support innovative enterprises and green infrastructure in european regions until 2020 .
these are not recognised by the uk as legal obligations .
with such uncertainty , how can we build trust and start discussing a future relationship ?
davis said the uk had a very different legal stance '' on the issue of financial obligations .
and , although the uk would pay what it owed , the government had an obligation to taxpayers to challenge what the eu was demanding , he said .
the commission has set out its position and we have a duty to our taxpayers to interrogate it rigorously .
at this round we presented our legal analysis , on on-budget issues , on off-budget issues , and on the eib - european investment bank .

it 's fair to say across the piece we have a very different legal stance , but as we said in the article 50 letter the settlement should be in accordance with law and in the spirit of the uk 's continuing partnership with the eu .
davis also said , during the q & a , that britain was a country that met its obligations but that those obligations have got to be well specified , they 've got to be real . ''
davis also said the uk would acknowledge its moral obligations , as well as its legal obligations , when agreeing what to pay the eu .
talking about the obligations the uk would meet , he said : they do n't necessarily have to be legal .
we also recognise moral obligations sometimes .
barnier said he was willing to speed up the pace of talks if necessary .

he said : time is flying , it is passing very quickly , if we need to , we on our side , on behalf of the 27 , are prepared on behalf of the eu institutions to step up and intensify the rhythm of the negotiations .
davis claimed that some concrete progress '' had been made this week .
this week we have had long and detailed discussions across multiple areas and i think it 's fair to say we have seen some concrete progress , and michel referred to one but there 's more than that .
davis said that both sides had reached agreement in some new areas relating to citizens ' rights .
in his opening speech he said : this week we have discussed a wide range of issues which will have a significant impact on people 's lives .
in particular , both sides have agreed : to protect the rights of frontier workers .
to cover future social security contributions for those covered by the withdrawal agreement .
that we should at least protect existing healthcare rights and arrangements for eu27 citizens in the uk and uk nationals in the eu .
the ehic [ european health insurance card ] arrangements .

that is good news for example , for british pensioners in the eu : it means that they will continue to have their health care arrangements protected both where they live and - when they travel to another member state - to be able to use an ehic card .
on economic rights , we have secured the right of british citizens in the eu27 to set up and manage a business within their member state of residence , and of course visa versa .
on mutual recognition of qualifications , we have made progress in protecting the recognition of qualifications for british citizens resident in the eu27 and eu27 citizens in the uk .
for every one of these , of course , in fact every single thing i 've said , all of these are reciprocal , they work for brits in the eu and the eu27 in the uk .
davis claimed that the uk was being more flexible and pragmatic '' than the eu .

our discussions this week have exposed yet again that the uk 's approach is substantially more flexible and pragmatic than that of the eu , as it avoids unnecessary disruption for businesses and consumers .

barnier said that the home office decision to send letters ( mistakenly ) to 100 eu nationals threatening them with deportation highlighted the case for the european court of justice having a role protecting the rights of eu citizens after brexit .
this is something brussels is demanding but the uk is resisting .
barnier said in his opening remarks : over the summer , around one hundred eu and eea citizens living lawfully in the uk received deportation letters .
the uk government quickly recognised that this was a mistake .
but this is not the first time that something like this has happened .

it reinforces the need to ensure that citizens ' rights are directly enforceable in front of national jurisdictions , under the control of the european court of justice , a point on which we disagree today .
barnier urged people not to underestimate the important of the european parliament in the brexit process .

he made this point in his opening remarks when he stressed that he was operating under a mandate agreed by eu leaders that says trade talks should not start under sufficient progress has been made on withdrawal issues .
the european parliament has also passed a resolution , by a large majority , saying the same thing .
david davis ( left ) and michel barnier at their press conference in brussels .
mayo/ap
here is the full text of what david davis said in his opening remarks at the press conference .
here is the text of michel barnier 's opening remarks at the press conference .
but it is as delivered - so most of it is in french .
daniel ferrie ( @ danielferrie ) speech by @ twitterid at the end of round 3 of the # brexit negotiations :
this is from the daily express 's brussels correspondent nick gutteridge .
nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) press room here genuinely stunned by that - nobody expected that level of antagonism between the pair .
is a british walkout now inevitable ?
here is my colleague jessica elgot 's story about the press conference .
no decisive progress on key brexit issues , says eu 's chief negotiator read more
the former prime minister tony blair had a meeting with jean-claude juncker , the european commission president , in brussels today .
given that blair has made no secret of the fact that he would like to kibosh brexit altogether , the scheduling of the meeting has led to speculation by brexiteers that is he up to something .
but the commission has issued a statement about the meeting suggesting that brexit was not at the top of the agenda .

the two met because they have known each other for long time since they served simultaneously as heads of government of their respective countries during 10 years , the entire length of blair 's time as prime minister '' , the commission said .

it said the two men exchanged views on a wide number of issues of european and international interest , from the state of the european economy to international trade , to the situation in the middle east and north africa - which blair knows well as former special envoy of the middle east quartet - and the future of the european union . ''
tony blair ( right ) being welcomed by european commission president jean claude juncker in brussels this morning .
hoslet/epa
eu officials were briefing journalists after the press conference .
here are some of the tweets from journalists about what was being said .

from my colleague lisa o'carroll lisa o'carroll ( @ lisaocarroll ) eu senior official says brit proposals for irish border customs `` are predicated on the eu suspending the application of its own laws '' 1/2 lisa o'carroll ( @ lisaocarroll ) 2/2 eu knocks back brit proposals for irish border customs : `` we do n't consider that a sound basis '' .

`` we have to design a stand alone soln '' from the telegraph 's james crisp james crisp ( @ jamescrisp6 ) eu wo n't accept cut and paste of eu standards into uk law as enough for mutual recognition , says senior official .
1/2 james crisp ( @ jamescrisp6 ) for mutual recognition ( vital for trade ) of standards , there must be same suopervisory and enforcement mechanisms .

uk does n't get that 2/2 from the express 's nick gutteridge nick gutteridge ( @ nick gutteridge ) eu official insists uk will have to pay brexit bill and budget contributions for sm access during transition .
an 'independent discussion ' .

documents.title: davis/barnier press conference - snap analysis
text: that was easily the most awkward and inaus press conference we 've had in the brexit talks process so far .
it was not bad-tempered , but it left the impression that the gulf between the two sides is getting wider , not narrower .
what was perhaps most telling was that david davis and michel barnier could not even agree on how things were going .
davis presented a relatively upbeat , business-as-usual '' take on what has been going on .
but barnier , in a measured but faintly menacing manner , suggested that the uk was still living in la-la land .
it had not fully accepted the implications of leaving the single market and that what it was demanding was impossible '' , he said .
here are some of the key lines .
barnier said the uk demands relating to access to the single market were impossible '' .
the uk wanted to leave the single market and customs union , he said .
but it also wanted its standards automatically recognised by the eu .
that was unrealistic , he said .
he said the single market must not and will not be undermined brexit '' .
he said he was quite far '' from being able to advise eu leaders to open phase two of brexit talks - the bit dealing with the future trade relationship - in october as planned .
he said the talks suggested the uk did not feel legally obliged to honour its obligations to the eu after brexit .
he said there had been no decisive progress '' on the key issues in this week 's talks .
davis said the uk would take into account its moral obligations as well as its legal obligations in its brexit offer to the eu .
i will post a much more detailed summary , with all the key quotes , soon .
davio davis ( left ) and michel barnier at the press conference .
dunand/afp/getty images
q : what are the chances of making sufficient progress to move on to the next stage of the talks by the october european council ?
and if that deadline is missed , will it have to wait until the december council ?
barnier says the quality of the agreement matters more than that amount of time taken .
davis says he agrees .
and that 's it .
i will post a summary and reaction shortly .

documents.title: davis says uk will take into account its moral obligations as well as its legal obligations in its brexit offer to eu
text: q : [ to davis ] do you admit that not publishing any financial proposals is not helpful ?
and what do you think of tony blair being in brussels today to meet jean-claude juncker ?
davis says he will not comment on the blair/juncker meeting .
he says the government has been trying to establish if the legal obligations laid down by the eu are properly codified .
he says the uk will meet its obligations .
but those obligations have to be real , he says .
he also says they do not necessarily have to be legal .
the government recognises moral obligations too , he says .
davis says uk will take into account its moral obligations as well as its legal obligations in its brexit offer to eu .
q : [ to barnier ] are you seeing any sign from the uk they are being flexible ?
barnier says the uk has decided to leave the eu .
the government has said it will leave the single market and the customs unions .
he says he is following the guidelines he has been set .
some of the issues may have not been debated in sufficient depth in the uk , he says .
he says he hopes there will be a debate in the uk about what being in the single market means .
he will be happy to take part .
reading some of the british papers , he says a sort of nostalgia '' .
there are requests to enjoy the benefit of the single market without being part of it , he says .
he says he must respect the integrity of the single market .
it is not we who are leaving .
it is the uk that is leaving the eu .
q : [ to davis ] are you seeing any signs the eu is being flexible ?
davis says he would not mistake belief in the free market for nostalgia .
he says the phrase he has used , flexible and imaginative solutions '' , is a quote from the european council .
he thinks they are right .

documents.title: davis and barnier 's q & a
text: james mates from itv goes first .
q : [ to davis ] are you providing clarity or constructive ambiguity ?
davis says constructive ambiguity '' ( a phrase he applied in a today interview , describing what happens in negotiations sometimes ) was not his phrase but kissinger 's .
the prime minister has been very clear about what the uk wants , he says .
q : [ to barnier ] is there any chance of sufficient progress being made by october .
barnier rejects the suggestion he is angry or frustrated .
he thinks he has shown the ty calm of a mountaineer .
if he does get angry , it will be obvious , he says .
he says , to succeed , they both must be as constructive and as unambiguous as possible .
davis says there is a high degree of convergence on ireland and on the common travel areas .
there are been almost complete agreement on privilege issues , and on confidentiality .
he says the uk 's approach is more pragmatic than the eu 's on some issues .
the third round of talks has been productive , he says .
davis says barnier spoke about the timetable .
davis says he always said there would be turbulence .
but both sides are trying to be constructive .
let 's continue to work together constructively , he says .
he says his team will publish further papers in the coming weeks .
on the financial settlement , davis says the uk has a duty to taxpayers to interrogate the eu 's position .
this week it has done that .
the uk has a different legal stance , he says .
but he says the uk accepts that there must be a settlement in accordance with the law , and in the interests of the future relationship .
there are still significant differences to be bridged , he says .
david davis is speaking now .
he starts by thanking the delegations for their work .
this week there have been long and detailed discussion over many areas .
there has been concrete progress '' in a number of areas , he says .
but there is still some way to go , he says .
he says he wanted to establish this week where they agree and disgree .
the uk 's approach has been informed by a series of detailed papers , he says .
they represent the outcome of hard work .
they offer pragmatic solutions .
they propose options , not a single approach .
issues relating to withdrawal and the future relations are inextricably linked '' , he says .
at the heart of this process must be a desire to deliver the best outcome , he says .
citizens ' rights remain a key issue .
both sides have agreed to protect the rights of frontier workers .
british pensioners in the eu will continue to be able to use a health card , where they live and if they travel in the eu .
the uk will soon publish a comparison on the uk and eu positions , he says .
barnier turns to financial obligations .
he says this week it has become clear that the uk does not accept that it needs to recognise its financial obligations after brexit .
how can we establish trust on that basis , he asks .
he reverts back to french .
he says he always said this would be complex .
over the last three days he has seen a lot of commitment on both sides , he says .
he says he is prepared to intensify negotiations .
barnier criticises the uk for the letters that have gone out to some eu nationals saying they must leave the uk .

documents.title: barnier says uk demands relating to access to single market are 'impossible '
text: barnier says he is quite far '' from being able to say to eu leaders in october that enough progress has been made to move the talks on at that point to cover the future trade relationship .
barnier says he is quite far '' from being able to advise eu leaders to open phase two of brexit talks in october .
he says he wants to stress three points .
he says he has a mandate , saying he must focus on three issues first : the rights of eu nationals , ireland and financial obligations .
the european parliament also agrees , he says .
he says the uk should not underestimate the importance of the parliament .
barnier has now switched to speaking in english , from french .
he says protecting the integrity of the single market is central to his mandate .
the single market must not and will not be undermined brexit '' , he says .
barnier says the single market must not and will not be undermined brexit '' .
he says he uk wants to take back control .
but it also wants to have uk standards automatically recognised by the eu .
this is simply impossible .
barnier says uk demands relating to access to the single market are impossible '' .

documents.title: barnier says there has been no decisive progress '' on the key issues in brexit talks
text: michel barnier opens the press conference .
the third round of talks has concluded , he says .
he says on monday he said he was concerned .
time is passing quickly , he says .
on 29 march 2019 , at the stroke of midnight , the uk will leave the eu .
will we have organised a properly , orderly exit for the uk ?
or will it be leaving without an agreement , with all the consequences already explained .
he says it is in the interests of europe for the uk to leave with agreement .
this week there have been a number of useful clarifications .
he lists a few .
however we did not get any decisive progress on any of the principal subjects '' .
barnier says there has been no decisive progress '' on the key issues in brexit talks .

documents.title: david davis and michel barnier hold press conference after brexit talks
text: david davis , the brexit secretary , and michel barnier , the eu 's chief brexit negotiator , are about to hold a press conference after this week 's talks .
as my colleague jennifer rankin reports , the talks have not been going smoothly .
uk tells brussels negotiators their brexit bill sums do not add up read more
harry cole ( @ mrharrycole ) may + abe sign memo to `` work quickly to establish a new economic partnership between japan and the uk based on the final terms of the epa . ''
here is some more media comment on the may/abe press conference .

from the telegraph 's gordon rayner gordon rayner ( @ gordonrayner ) theresa may hits back at mps accusing her of hubris over leadership comments , saying public wants her to get on with the job in hand from the sun 's harry cole harry cole ( @ mrharrycole ) pm hits back at party critics - says public watching and want her to get on with the job of running country .
harry cole ( @ mrharrycole ) abe still cool on future trade deal .
hails new era and set up a working group with may for future free trade after brexit .

documents.title: may/abe press conference - summary
text: that was a press conference that was rather light on the news front , but two points did emerge .
may brushed aside complaints from tories about her declaration that she wants to fight the next election by saying that the public want her to get on with the job '' .
she did not resile from what she said yesterday , and she repeated the line about not being a quitter .
but , equally , she used less provocative language than she did yesterday .

she did not talk about fighting the next election , and she acknowledged that what mattered was delivery ( a point grant shapps made this morning - see 10.03am ) - not ( by implication ) speculating about the next election .
if she had answered the election leadership question with this line yesterday , there would have been no story .

at the press conference , when asked how she responded to tory mps who were not happy about her comments about wanting to fight the next election as party leader , she replied : i said i was n't a quitter and there is a long-term job to do .

there is an important job to be done in the united kingdom , we stand at a really critical time in the uk [ long-term issues like mental health ] are real issues that we need to be dealing with and i 'm there to do it .
for most members of the public , they would say they want the government to get on with the job and that 's exactly what i and the government are doing .
abe said he was encouraged by the assurances given by may about delivering a smooth brexit .
abe acknowledged that brexit was a concern to japanese investors .
but his warm comments about the assurances he has received will be welcomed by number 10 , and cited as evidence that may is handling brexit in a business-friendly way .
abe said : i have trust in the uk economy after brexit .
many japanese companies , even after the brexit vote , have decided on new investments into the united kingdom .
this is testimony to japanese companies ' expectations of the united kingdom .
from the uk in the eu exit negotiation there has to be transparency and predictability to minimise any damage on the businesses .
we have received that commitment and we value this greatly .
even after brexit the uk , for business people , it will continue to be a compelling place .
i am convinced of that .
carl dinnen from itv goes next .
q : you say that china needs to put more pressure on north korea .
but the chinese media says you are in a weak position ?
may says the world should be putting pressure on china to rein in north korea .
q : some tory mps think you will have to quit as leader .
what is your response ?
may says she said she was not a quitter .
there is an important job to be done , she says .
brexit is important , but there are other issues to address as well .
she set them out when she became prime minister .
for example , mental health .
these are real issues .
most members of the public just want the government to get on with the job '' .
q : [ to abe ] have you heard enough from may to be sure japanese companies wo n't leave the uk after brexit ?
abe says the uk is the gateway to europe for japanese companies .
he put this to may .
she responded in a forceful way .
that was encouraging , he says .
he says may 's position has been appreciated by japanese companies .
some have made new investments in the uk .
he says he is confident the uk will respond favourably to japanese concerns .
and that 's it .
the press conference is over .
i will post a summary very shortly .

documents.title: may and abe 's q & a
text: there will be two questions .
the first comes from a japanese journalist .
but it is a two-part question .
q : brexit is due to happen in march 2019 .
there is still concern about the adverse impact on japanese companies .
what do you expect future economic relations to be like ?
abe says he took may to a tea ceremony yesterday .
he wanted her to see japanese culture .
there was only one foreign implement there .
it was a porcelain pitcher , made in the uk .
it fitted in very well with the japanese things .
he suggests this is symbolic of the depth of the relationship .
japan and the uk are mutually important countries , he says .
he says japan wants to minimise the impact of brexit on japanese companies .
he says he has presented his requests to may .
may told him she would be listening to the voices of japanese companies and wanted brexit to go ahead in a smooth and orderly way , he says .
he says this encouraged him greatly .
q : how did you feel about the north korean threat ?
abe says north korea has conducted two icbm missile tests .
the range could include almost all europe , he says .
he says he put out a joint statement on north korea with may .
the security environment is becoming tougher , he says .
that is why the closest partners in europe and asia ( ie , the uk and japan ) must cooperate .
may attended a national security council meeting today .
( see 9.07am . )
may is speaking now .
she says the cooperation between the uk and japan is particularly important now with north korea posing an unprecedented threat '' .
she says the uk and japan are natural partners .
they are both island nations with global reach .
today they have committed to elevating their partnership in a number of area .
japan is a natural partner to the uk on security .
japan and the uk are each other 's closest partners in europe and asia respectivley .
may says defence cooperation is being stepped up .
next year british troops with exercise with their japanese counterparts in japan for the first time ever .
she says the north korea missile launch was an outrageous provocation '' and an unacceptable threat to japan .
she and abe have agreed to work together in the international community to increase pressure on north korea , including by strengthening sanctions .
japan is the world 's third largest economy .
the uk benefits more from its investment than from investment from any other country except the us .
the uk hopes japanese firms have a long-term presence in the uk .
japanese investors have told her they remain committed to the uk .
and abe expressed his support for the uk economy after brexit .
she says the uk expects to be able to sign trade deals in the interim period after brexit ( ie , the transitional period ) .
they are working on a deal with japan , she says .
she says her first visit to japan has been memorable .
she has seen its rich traditional culture and its modern dynamism .
this visit marks a great step forward , she says .
the uk and japan will be standard-bearers for the open world order both countries rely on .
abe says he and may discussed improving anglo-japanese cooperation , especially in addressing policy issues like the problems created by an ageing society .
he says this marks the dawning of a new era in anglo-japanese relations .
abe says it is important for the uk to have a smooth and successful '' brexit .
he says he has asked may to ensure transparency , to help minimise the impact on japanese companies .
abe says the uk is an important player in the asian pacific .
he says the uk has agreed to share its olympic expertise with japan , which is hosting the games in 2020 .

jason farrell ( @ jasonfarrellsky ) japan pm - `` we are living in a world of change and uncertainty '' jason farrell ( @ jasonfarrellsky ) japan pm straight in talking about the `` grave threat '' posed by north korea .
saying today agreed with may to increase pressure on the country

documents.title: theresa may 's press conference in japan
text: theresa may is now holding her press conference in japan with her japanese counterpart , shinzo abe .
abe opens the press conference with a statement .
he says the north korea missile test , which involved a missile flying over japan , was outrageous .
the guido fawkes blog has found nine tory mps willing to say publicly that they support theresa may 's desire to stay on as party leader until the next election .
but some of the nine do n't seem overly keen on the prospect .
one on the guido list is keith simpson , who told politico europe : frankly , what is she going to say . ''
interestingly , those mps most keeping may are ardent brexiteers ( eg , peter bone , nadine dorries and nigel evans . )
it looks as if it will be bit of a squash in the room for the may/abe press conferences .

jason farrell ( @ jasonfarrellsky ) sky news team has a bit of a scrum to get in poll position for theresa may /shinzo abe press conference my colleague peter walker fears there will be more flags than questions peter walker ( @ peterwalker99 ) setting for the imminent may/abe press conference .
three sets of flags , no less .
peter walker ( @ peterwalker99 ) three sets of flags , but seemingly only one question per country .
it 's a lot of media gathered for not much information .
sky has released some overnight polling figures that suggest the tories would be better off getting rid of theresa may before the next general election .

sky data ( @ skydata ) new sky data pollwould it be good or bad for the tories if may leads them into the next election ? good 28 % bad 45 % neither 18 % dont know 9 % sky data ( @ skydata ) would you be more or less likely to vote tory if may resigned ? more 17 % less 9 % no difference 64 % do n't know 10 % the detailed figures suggest that having may as leader harms the tories with younger voters , but makes less difference amongst over-55s .

sky data ( @ skydata ) good or bad for tories if may is still leader at next election ? 18-34good 16 % bad 60 % 35-54good 29 % bad 41 % 55+good 37 % bad 36 % sky data polls involve surveys of sky customers .
but the results are weighted to make them nationally representative , and this works pretty well as a polling strategy because sky has such a large customer database .
effectively , they are using their customers as a version of the online panel used by companies like icm or yougov .
this is from sky 's jason farrell .
jason farrell ( @ jasonfarrellsky ) japanese press pack wait for conference with theresa may .
kezia dugdale , who resigned on tuesday as scottish labour leader , has claimed she was outed by a magazine before she had publicly revealed she is gay .

speaking to the bbc 's victoria derbyshire programme , dugdale said she asked for her quotes on her sexuality not to be included in an interview with the fabian review in 2016 - a claim disputed by the journalist who wrote the piece .
dugdale told the programme : it was n't the first time i 'd been asked [ by journalists ] about my sexuality .
i would always answer honestly , and then i would say 'i 'd prefer you did n't use that i do n't think it matters ' .
up until that day , everybody had respected that , and then that one journalist had decided no , it was a story .
mary riddell , the journalist who conducted the interview , said dugdale did not ask her not to publish anything about her sexuality .
she said : during my fabian interview with kezia dugdale , she volunteered that she had a female partner and spoke briefly about that relationship as a source of strength .
i had no knowledge before the interview either of her sexuality or whether she was in a relationship .
at no point during the interview or afterwards did she ask me not to publish her comments , which were recorded with her agreement .
nor has she ever complained to me that her on-the-record comments relating to her relationship had been published .
kezia dugdale .

macleod for the guardian sir alan duncan , the deputy foreign secretary and the first tory mp to come out , also told the victoria derbyshire programme that being gay led to him being blocked from becoming a whip during john major 's government .
he said he was blackballed from the whip 's office '' by people who thought it would be too high-risk '' .
he came out in 2002 , reasoning that i 'd reached the point , having been in parliament for 10 years , where i thought i was senior enough not to be dismissed '' .
sir alan duncan .
altan/afp/getty images

documents.title: grant shapps ' today interview - summary
text: here is a summary of the main points from grant shapps ' interview about theresa may on the today programme earlier .
shapps , a former conservative chair , said that the tories were unlikely to let may lead them into the next general election .
asked if he agreed with lord heseltine , who said that no one in the party wanted to see may up against jeremy corbyn at the next election , he said : i think that is probably the case .
the truth is , we ran a very poor election .

and you ca n't just brush that under the table , pretend it did n't happen , not least because we went from having a workable majority to no majority at all you ca n't go pretending it was n't anything other than a disastrous result .
he said may 's comments in japan would raise some eyebrows '' in the party .
i think colleagues may well be surprised by this interview last night and i think it is too early to be talking about going on and on , as margaret thatcher once said .
let 's get some progress for the british people first , i think that 's the priority .
he said that it would be for the party , not for may herself , to decide whether she led them into the next election .
and that is what may herself said when she addressed tory mps at the 1922 committee just after the election , he said .
but he suggested that tory mps would want to judge may on her performance before taking a final decision about her future .
there was no desire in the party for a leadership contest now , he said .
we 've got this massive brexit thing coming up .
she 's got 18 months .

i think , speaking to colleagues - i must have had conversations with about 50 or so colleagues during the summer - and the overwhelming feeling is , she 's there , she has a job to do , we 've got this massive brexit deal to sort out .
and then let 's see what the performance looks like .
i would have thought that that is the common sense approach .
in a week where we 've been talking about boardroom responsibility , the person at the top must take responsibility .
and you have to see what the performance is like .
nick robinson interviewed shapps .
here is his take on what shapps was saying .
nick robinson ( @ bbcnickrobinson ) the party will decide your future not you - former tory chairman @ twitterid tells theresa may @ twitterid4today grant shapps .
argles for the guardian
this is from sky 's lewis goodall .
lewis goodall ( @ lewis goodall ) senior tory mp tells me : `` my concern is that theresa may actually believes what she has said .
she is delusional . ''
theresa may is due to be holding a press conference with her japanese counterpart , shinzo abe , within the next hour .
my colleague peter walker is travelling with her and he has posted these on twitter .
peter walker ( @ peterwalker99 ) we 're at tokyo 's akasaka palace , now a state guest house , where theresa may & shinzo abe are holding a press conference soon .
peter walker ( @ peterwalker99 ) may and abe are already inside , holding formal talks - they 've spent a fair bit of time together since may arrived yesterday .
it wo n't be a very extensive press conference , though .
journalists have been told that there could just be two questions allowed

one argument being made about theresa may 's comment about wanting to fight the next general election as conservative leader is that she had to say what she did because if she had said she did not want to lead the party into the next election , she would declared herself a lame duck and triggering a fresh round of leadership speculation .
but the sun 's political editor tom newton dunn points out that in an interview in july , may managed to dodge the question with an alternative formula that did not seem to do her any harm .
tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) the pm has made a second bad decision while hill walking again .
declaring you 'll go on and on a bad look for her .
maybe the beach next hol .
tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) she could have repeated the below , which is what she told me in july , @ twitterid .
no less of a lame duck today .
newton dunn is probably right about may not having to answer the question quite as firmly as she did .
but he is comparing an answer given in a print interview with answers given in interviews on camera to broadcasters .
it is harder to get away with fudge and evasion on camera because it makes you look shifty to the viewers .
that may help to explain why may was more committal in what she said in japan - although , of course , viewers will form their own judgment about whether she really believed what she was saying .

shinzo abe , the japanese prime minister , has promised theresa may his country will remain committed to the uk after brexit , but said businesses need transparency and predictability '' during the process of leaving the eu , my colleague peter walker reports .

japan remains committed to uk after brexit , abe tells may read more theresa may , and japan 's defence minister itsunori onodera listen to the two countries ' national anthems on board the japanese navy 's helicopter carrier js izumo during a visit to yokosuka naval base earlier today .
court/getty images may attending japan 's national security council meeting in tokyo , sitting with the japanese prime minister shinzo abe on her left .
/reuters
here is my colleague matthew weaver 's round-up of reaction this morning to theresa may 's declaration that she wants to fight the next election .
senior tories cast doubt on theresa may 's long-term future as leader read more

katie perrior , who worked for theresa may as her communications director in downing street until the general election , told the today programme that she did not expect may to lead the party into the next general election .
( perrior fell out with may 's co chiefs of staff nick timothy and fiona hill , but she not does seem to bear a grudge against may , about whom she is generally very positive . )
theresa may told journalists on her trip to japan that she wants to lead her party into another general election .

her comments were only reported last night , and this morning the former conservative party chair , grant shapps , responded by saying that the tories would probably want another leader by the time of the next election .
he told the today programme that may should concentrate on showing colleagues that she could deliver brexit .
i think colleagues may well be surprised by this interview last night and i think it is too early to be talking about going on and on , as margaret thatcher once said .
let 's get some progress for the british people first , i think that 's the priority .
but he also said that it was probably the case '' that nobody in the party wanted may to face jeremy corbyn at the ballot box again .
nicky morgan , education secretary until she was sacked by may , also told the bbc that she did not expect may to lead the party into the next election .
i think it 's going to be difficult for theresa may to lead us into the next general election , '' morgan told the bbc 's hardtalk programme .
( after the election morgan was saying may should quit by the end of the year . )
i will post more reaction to the may interview , including more from what shapps said on today , shortly .
later this morning ( uk time ) may is due to give a press conference in japan .
and after that we should get a press conference with david davis , the brexit secretary , and michel barnier , the eu 's chief brexit negotiator , at the end of this week 's round of brexit talks .
i will be focusing on the may leadership story and on the two press conferences .
but , as usual , i will be covering breaking political news as it happens , as well as bringing you the best reaction , comment and analysis from the web .
you can read all today 's guardian politics stories here .
if you want to follow me or contact me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
i try to monitor the comments btl but normally i find it impossible to read them all .
if you have a direct question , do include andrew '' in it somewhere and i 'm more likely to find it .
i do try to answer direct questions , although sometimes i miss them or do n't have time .
if you want to attract my attention quickly , it is probably better to use twitter .

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of the day's political developments as they happen, including Theresa May's press conference in Japan and the David Davis/Michel Barnier press conference at the end of the Brexit talks.
Theresa May's press conference with Shinzo Abe - Summary.
Davis/Barnier Brexit press conference - Snap analysis.
